turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Number 263, Rudolf Ivanovich Abel, etcetera, versus -- Petitioner, versus United States of America.
Mr. Solicitor General, you may continue your argument.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.
I'd like to address myself first to -- in trying to answer the last inquiry from Mr. Justice Brennan.
The -- the question was in regard to interviews with Mr. Hayhanen and when he might have been indicated his willingness for the first time to testify as I understood the question.
And --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: With relation to the -- search in relation to --

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: The first time that there was any indication that he was willing to testify in July 21st of that same year, 1957, they interviewed him again after the interviews on the 18th and 19th of June in which he refused.

On July 11th, the first time following June 18th and 19th, he continued to refuse to be willing to testify and then he was interviewed from time to time up to the 21st when he did indicate his willingness to -- to testify.
He was then -- he was then presented to the grand jury as of the 5th and 6th and the indictment was returned on the 7th of August.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: As I understood it, the first presentation to the grand jury was after July (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: That's right.
Now, an inquiry was made by Justice Stewart in regard to prosecution for illegal entry, and there is a statute providing that that is a misdemeanor, but the statute is -- has a five-year limitation.
The evidence is that this man entered the country back in 1949, according to his own testimony.
We thought perhaps it might have been 1948.
We checked it back through and found from a manifest that he did enter under the name he gave in 1949 and so, that statute would have run.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: The fact that he refused to report to the Attorney General's continued offense.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: So in your own opinion (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Coming from the District of Connecticut.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: (Inaudible) yes.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: Remember this question of what's the (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: The limitation wasn't here.
I just wondered --

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: -- being a continuing offence and following the man where he goes under our opinion.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: It probably could be.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: (Inaudible) limitations apply.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: So we'd rather to take that off it.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: [Laughs]

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, is it a different statute that requires him to report to the Attorney General?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes, and --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And that is a (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: A misdemeanor too.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: That's a misdemeanor too.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Did the statute run on that?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: No, it had not.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: That would be open, but we would have to have the testimony of Hayhanen to establish that misdemeanor and convict him under it.

Now, at the time that the Latham Hotel was entered for the arrest is the position of the Government that there were -- there was probable cause although we didn't have -- we couldn't have the testimony of Mr. Hayhanen for the trial and therefore, we felt we had no chance to convict.
Nevertheless, there was probable cause on the violation of the statute in regard to the misdemeanor for not reporting to the Attorney General.
There was probable cause with -- that's been conceded here in regard to the violations of the conspiracy to commit espionage.
There was probable cause in regard to the right of deportation.
And if the statute of limitations hadn't run, there was probable cause in regard to the illegal entry, all of those at the time of the entry into the Hotel Latham.
Before closing last night, I related the evidence in regard to the Immigration Service determining that this man should be deported.
The lower court found that the Immigration Service did make that decision and that the F.B.I.did not make it.

The lower court also found that the good faith of the Government and the Immigration Service throughout in this proceeding of trying to deport this man, and the Court of Appeals affirmed that after reviewing the evidence and the position of the Government that in light of that, unless, there is an error as a matter of law, that should be accepted in this Court and a matter of good faith is peculiarly a -- a question of the credibility of the witnesses appearing before the Court and therefore, it is a matter that the Court -- this Court should leave unless there is an error as a matter of law.
Now, keeping in mind --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Mr. Solicitor --

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- General, surely in a case of this kind involving a man allegedly with his identity, the matter must have gone pretty high into the Justice Department for a decision, did it not?
What's the record showing that?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: The highest that it shows was that there was the information -- the examination of it by the Internal Security Division.
And they concluded that without Hayhanen's testimony, they could not prove the case in a trial under an indictment.

Then it went to General Swing, the Commissioner of Immigration Service, in that the probable cause information for a warrant for deportation was related to him, but the evidence is that Mr. Noto, who is in charge of Special Investigations for Immigration Service, was the one who made the decision to deport and to issue the warrant and he had the authority under the regulations.
He did direct that the warrant be prepared and issued and that the order to show cause be prepared and issued.

So, that the problem of the Department had at that time was that here was a man who has many question, who was a colonel in the espionage apparatus, one -- the highest man we've ever located in this country, that had been working in this country in that service for a period of eight or nine years at this time.
We knew that he had been active.
We had all these evidence to the fact of his activity in this espionage work during this period and corroborating evidence.
But --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: My -- my last -- my question was directed to --

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- to your -- what you've told us about the findings of fact in the Court -- in the District Court which were accepted -- accepted by the Court of Appeals that this was a good faith decision on the part of the Immigration and Naturalization people to effect this arrest, that there was evidence of corroboration between that part of the Justice Department and between the F.B.I., another part of the Justice Department, but the one was not acting as the secret agent of the other.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I was wondering if -- if there was any effort in addition to that of -- of -- if there was any evidence in addition to the evidence of cooperation, if there was any evidence of coordination by somebody above each of these Departments using one where it would be useful and the other where it would be useful.
Is there any such evidence out of coordination from above?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Not in -- in that respect.

I think that the -- the inference can be drawn that it was concluded that Internal Security Division had come to the conclusion that they couldn't prosecute because without Hayhanen, and therefore, the question was, “What could be done to stop this man from continuing as an espionage agent working in this country?”
And that the best thing left was to deport him.
At least he couldn't keep on working to try to obtain and divulge the securities about the internal security of this country and its defense.

And so I think that it's apparent from the record and both courts concluded that that was the purpose that they felt they couldn't prove the others, although they had probable cause and grounds for an arrest, they -- they couldn't go in the Court and prove it and therefore, they want to stop this man from continuing to operate on the country as an espionage agent.
So they proceeded this other way that the statutes give the power to the Attorney General to act, and he proceeded to do it and act in good faith.
And then they came upon this additional evidence, which was not necessary if they had Hayhanen, what was cumulated.
No question about it in regard to the espionage matter.
And it's a question of whether under the decisions they had to pass that up or whether they could take it as a part of a proper search and seizure and -- and actually the deportation.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Did Hayhanen testify at the trial?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes, he did.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: What brought about his change of attitude?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Is that shown on the record?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: It's not shown.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Mr. Solicitor, may I ask this particularly if you have time to deal with it at the time that you have left?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I would like to know what the relevance of good faith (Inaudible) so the test to the fact of good faith is the question whether or not the Fourth Amendment has or has not in this regard.
What's the relevance of that?
Even --

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- assuming that the Harris case says so known use to you that the Harris case had been constantly on the trier in this Court raising a constitutional question which can only be opened up --

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes.
The --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- if you have time in your --

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- scheme of argument.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes.
The Harris --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) that simple question for me.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: The Harris case does speak of good faith and the fact that there was good faith in the search and seizure (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Which I do not doubt meaning by good faith that it was conscientiously being this is the wise and right thing to do.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Is that a fair definition of good faith?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, I think there's also a claim here that we didn't really want to deport this man, that we were just using it as a subterfuge or device, and that therefore, by such a device, we couldn't go around and collect evidence in a search and seizure by that means.
And they compared it with a case where the man slipped into the office of a man on the representation we're just making a visit.
You recall (Inaudible) case.
And in that case, he then proceeded to make a search and seizure in a clumsy manner after he'd gotten in that way.
The Court said that was not a reasonable search and seizure in accordance with the Fourth Amendment.
I think that's the effort here to try to make it appear to be a subterfuge and not a valid deportation proceeding.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But my question didn't proceed from that assumption.
It proceeded from the contrary assumption.
This was simply the high-minded conscientiously conceived procedure on the part of the enforcing authority.

What I want to bring is what difference it makes from the point of view of the Fourth Amendment whether in a search or a seizure, they are not identical, which if there weren't some excuse with reference to deportation, would be on the wrong side of the Fourth Amendment.

What difference does it make that on the right side of the Fourth Amendment that -- that the steps that were taking or excusable or justifiable for purposes of deportation, but the proof of the enterprise is not to secure deportation but to get a conviction for a capital offense or maybe a capital offense.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, if --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That's my problem.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: If it was in a bad faith and a subterfuge, then you don't reach the basic question, I think, that you're directing to of whether or not it's proper to have a search and seizure under a deportation warrant in any event in accordance with the provisions or requirements of the Fourth Amendment.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Or -- or to have it for purpose of deportation.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Not usable for purposes of a criminal conviction, particularly of this kind of thing.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Proceeding to that, it seems to us in examining the cases the question is under the Amendment, what is a reasonable search and seizure?
Because that's what the Amendment says and that's what this Court had said.

And when you get the Latham Hotel, the search and the seizure that's involved in the first part, and I'll deal with the latter -- with the next step a little later, was by the Immigration Service and after they asked for this hearing as to cooperation and they got pass that and they got no cooperation, then the Immigration Service proceeded to make themselves known and that -- and present their credentials.
They asked the man what his name was.
And he said it was Martin Collins, which was one of the names on the -- was the name on one of the fraudulent birth certificates that he had that was discovered in the search.
They then proceeded, he was not dressed, and they told him to get dressed.
They presented their arrest warrant and their order to show cause and he receded the order to show cause.

They then asked him what clothes he want to take, what he -- what -- what he want to wear first, and they searched the clothes he was going to wear as to weapons and evidence of nationality or alienage.
And then they proceeded to ask him what he wanted to do about its things.
Did he want to take all his belongings with him?
And he said he did except for certain reservations.
And then they started it from a job of packing up.

Now, the only reason that you allow, as I understand it from the cases, the man to be searched with regard to weapons and anything that he might make an escape with is to protect the officers in carrying out their duty of serving the warrant.

And certainly that is necessary if you assume that a man has to be taken into custody for deportation, and certainly, he has to be taken into custody if it's in the interest of the protection of the country, which this certainly was within espionage agent.
All right.

When you -- when they examined him with regard to weapons and means of escape then the cases have held that if you run across evidence of the fruits of the transaction, illegal transaction, he's got some money on him, a robbery or anything like that, you can take that.
If he's got the means of committing other crimes, you can take that.
Now --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: If there were three -- three different groups of things taken, one -- some were on this person --

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes.

turn.text: -- is that right?

turn.text: Well, he tried to slip it up the sleeve after he got dressed.

turn.text: Well, that (Inaudible).

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, but that got on later.
He was -- he was not even dressed.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, no -- he -- he was naked, as I understand --

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- when the officers came in.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: But one thing was taken from his sleeve, is that right?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes, that's right.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Some things were taken from a waste paper basket?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: That's later.
Yes, by the F.B.I. after he'd given up the room.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: That's after -- that's after they came back?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: At the original time, one thing was taken from his sleeve and the rest were taken from the room at his request?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, yes.
They were taken from the room in the process of packing up his belongings.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Was that at his request?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes, he -- he said he wanted to take his belongings with him.
And they helped him pack.

And it's the position of the Government that it's unreasonable not to permit them to go through these various belongings and see whether he had any weapons or means of escape or any of the other contraband or any other unlawful means.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Anywhere in the room?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: That's right.
The room was only 8 by 12.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Some of them were.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Now, one was this -- the code message, that's the one that he was attempting to put up the sleeve.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Now, who took that?
The -- the Immigration agents or --

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: The Immigration.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Immigration.

Then the second group consisted of the false Martin Collins birth certificate, the false Emil Goldfus birth certificate, the vaccination certificate, Mark Collins and the bank book in favor of Goldfus.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Immigration --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Now, where -- where were each of those?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, those were in his belongings that were being packed.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, what I'm not quite clear about is when you say “in his belongings,” in the suits of clothes or in --

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: That isn't clear.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- dress drawers or something?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: That isn't clear --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: That doesn't appear?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: -- from the evidence.
No.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But again, who -- who was it that -- that found them?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: The Immigration agent.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.

turn.text: That then -- that would cover the sandpaper --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Now, the birth certificates, the vaccination certificate and the bank book, I take it, would all be relevant to a deportation proceeding, would they?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Oh, yes.
They would be a means by which he could maintain his -- his fictitious identity as he claimed he was Martin Collins here.
He also used the name Goldfus at his studio.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Now, what the -- what about the code message?
That would not be relevant, would it, to the deportation as such?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: No, but that he was trying to slip up his arm and was evidence, clear evidence of espionage.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Have the --

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: So it was a means of committing a crime and the courts held that you don't have to pass up a material of that kind, that you can take it if you run across it.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Now, may I get one other thing straight.
You've already told us that on the third category, those you -- the Government's position is they're admissible since they have been abandoned.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But on the other two categories, do you rest the admissibility of them as incident to the administrative warrant?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And not on any other ground?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, we -- we think there's no question of what -- there is grounds for an arrest, but he's criminal.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But the arrest, their admissibility as incident to a lawful arrest or as incident to the use of the administrative warrant?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, we urged before the Court the administrative warrant each time and its question whether the fact that there was grounds for arrest otherwise are sufficient under the -- the law or not.
They are, in some of the cases the Court has handed down and you might not be willing to recognize it here.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I'm -- I'm still not quite clear whether the Government is or isn't resting their admissibility as incident to a lawful arrest.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, we take the position that the Immigration warrant was a justification of warrant.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Is it fair -- is it fair to say or to assume that at no time during the period that the administrative warrant -- let me rephrase, I mean, that from the time that an administrative warrant was determined upon (Inaudible) that from that time on, there was already reasonable ground, speaking out technically or administratively that there -- in the minds of the Department that this is a potential espionage case as well.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes.
At all times, there was no question of what -- there was sufficient evidence that would get -- would get him to testify for an espionage case.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: So that coincident with pursuing means for getting in deported was the hope and desire that he -- that he also would be charged with a crime subject to criminal prosecution.
Is that a fair statement?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, not exactly because if we could have gotten a -- an espionage case against them, we certainly wouldn't have sought an immigration -- a deportation case.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I didn't mean that you had sufficient evidence in justifying the Government to go into court and put him to trial but it was in the mind of the authority that this is a potential spy case, is that right?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, it -- it was if we can get Hayhanen to testify, but we couldn't at that time and so, we --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: It's the thought of getting but not abandoned, in other words, the open expectation that it would turn out, as it did turn out had not been abandoned or -- in the case.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes, yes, it had.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: It had been a --

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: It had been abandoned.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: It -- it had been in a sense that they had concluded that they couldn't get Hayhanen to testify and the best thing to do is deport him.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I suppose also the Government had in mind if it would locate enough evidence of crime by a search that it would prosecute him for the -- the subversion even though Hayhanen didn't testify.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, I -- I think it would have, but he was very remote that could happen with such a skilled person.
And it's -- they didn't anticipate they could get the independent evidence that would be sufficient for that purpose.
They always had plenty and more than enough if Hayhanen would testify, but this man was a -- a very skilled operator and it was not expecting that he would leave around anything.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I think you answered -- you answered in -- didn't answer to a question of mine yesterday that it was not feasible to swear out of search warrant on secondary evidence by an F.B.I. agent because there would have been a disclosure which the Government was naturally not -- not willing to make, is that right?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: I think I -- that was my answer, yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That was to that point.

Now, the question I put to you this morning is on a different attack, namely, assuming such a difficulty confronted the Government could had circumvent, that -- that carries an odium which I do not need to carry -- convey, could the Government, as a matter of the Fourth Amendment, the new construction of the Fourth Amendment, could the Government abandon because of the difficulty of getting the appropriate witness or witnesses, could the Government abandon both of a criminal prosecution and yet proceed, assuming it could legally proceed, by way of deportation and make the administrative enforcer, the administrative warrant in the course of that make a search and make seizure which independently considered would not be warranted in the criminal case, nevertheless, use such products, a proof thereof in, what turned out to be happily, the basis of a criminal prosecution.
That's my problem that I put to you, and I hope you would have something to say about it.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Before you do that, I just want to call your attention to the fact that you naturally enough because the Court's opinion that even you leave to do so or lead you do to so, the Fourth Amendment doesn't say there may be reasonable search.
It doesn't --

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: It says there may not --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- say that.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: -- may not be unreasonable search --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: They may not be unreasonably that goes on as part of the same sentence to indicate what an unreasonable search is, namely, one without a warrant and the warrant specified to carry with it the detailed and the particularity that the Fourth Amendment enumerate and all the rest seizures without any warrant historically was doubtful, but (Inaudible) was talked about.
It was very doubtful whether you could make seizure even with a warrant.

And the Fourth Amendment put in the qualification which illuminated the first half of the Fourth Amendment what it is that constitutes an unreasonable search, namely, one without a warrant, and the case here is a matter of necessity like a fellow running away or there isn't group time for it, have read into that Amendment the qualifications that I -- I insist, if I may respectfully, that it's very important not to read that Amendment as authorizing reasonable search.
That's a gloss in -- from my point of view and on warrant of a gloss on the Fourth Amendment.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, of course, we have to deal with the decision of the Court.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: It takes them to get filed up, I started out by saying you have every warrant to say what --

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- you say.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: And the Court may reexamine Harris and decide that a warrant is necessary if there's time to secure, and we don't claim that there was not time to secure it in this matter because there was, but we weren't trying to search for anything in this case.
We were trying to deal with a very serious problem of an espionage agent and trying to take care of it since we couldn't have the witness by deporting him.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Mr. Solicitor General, you don't accept the theory of the petitioner that the record shows that what the Government perhaps really had in mind was the hope that this man, Abel, might cooperate with the Government and become a dual agent for.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: No --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: You say -- you say the record doesn't show that, do you?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: The only record on that is the claim of the petitioner himself, his affidavit.
He never did take the stand in this matter in support of that.
There's no other evidence, all the other evidence is to the contrary.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Was the affidavit admitted in connection with the motion to --

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- suppress the evidence?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Solicitor General, before you get to answering Mr. Justice Frankfurter's question, which I'm also anxious to hear you answer, gets the more on the bright side out of the way.

If you are wrong, the Government is wrong that any or all of this search and seizure cannot be supported on the administrative warrant, are you making any argument as to any of those items and if so, which ones that their admission in face of the fact that you get Hayhanen finally to testify was harmless error?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, we think it -- they were accumulated and the other evidence were so overwhelming that they would not be controlling in the case, but the code book is an important evidence on espionage in identifying Abel with us.
And certainly the code message was.
So those two items was --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: So if there were any harmless error, you'd limit that to those which are really related to the deportation, I gather, not so much to the espionage and that's the birth certificates, vaccination certificate and the bank book.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Could I ask a question?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, they've been used in the Court as -- tacitly recognizable that give her 70 years or more.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: What were the -- was there anything on the record -- perhaps the record will say what's been the practice of these -- these administrative warrants.
I -- are you opening that warrant by a search by the district?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, they've -- they've always been accompanied by a search to be sure they wouldn't kill the man that was trying to serve them.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes, and also the surroundings --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Surroundings.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: -- because otherwise, they'd be leaving themselves open to the --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: What -- what I'm trying to get at is whether (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: No, it was in accordance with the standard practice.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Where --

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: The only difference that there was in this case that I think there might not be in all cases was the inquiry as to whether he wanted to take his belongings because he was in the hotel room and he said he did.
And so that would necessitate the examination of those belongings to see if there was any weapons or anything of that kind in them.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: If I may interrupt you.

Is there -- where -- where can the -- are there any materials available anywhere in the Court's decisions or rules of the Department or anything else as to -- to support your statement, which, of course, I don't doubt that this was in accordance with the standard practice?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: There is an affidavit by Mr. Farley of the Immigration Service on page 68 of the record.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes, 68.

And then if you go down to the second full paragraph, the last sentence, this is customary practice after he's related the search and all, when aliens are arrested by Immigration and Naturalization Service officials on charges similar to those which led to this arrest.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: What about -- what about the (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, that's the only maximum security point that the Immigration Service had.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, what -- what did the order to show cause or turn into --

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: In New York, yes.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: In New York.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: I think it was the 24th, but I'm not sure.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: 10 days later.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible) already waiting there?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, if it wasn't already waiting, they certainly plan for it, I'm sure.
And he went to that hearing.
He's represented by counsel.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And that -- that's the hearing in response to the --

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Provision of the order to show cause?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: No objection was made.
And he then admitted that he was illegally in the country, that he come across Canada and -- and the whole case was admitted right there in regard to deportation.
He was already deported.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: Is it true when (Inaudible) under the law of security if (Inaudible) of the Immigration Service?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, Mr. Justice, the (Inaudible) has been changed in recent years.
We've given that up.
But if it doesn't involve security, they are provided in -- now in hotel rooms or other divisions in the -- in the area there in New York.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: New York?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes, and the statute gives a commission of the discretion.
In many of the cases, they're not retaining custody at all, but this was one where they didn't want him to operate another day, another moment on this espionage operation that they could help.
That was the whole purpose of trying to deport him, it was to get him so he wouldn't be able to operate anymore.
And the only place they had was this one at McAllen, Texas.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Am I right in -- in calling out cases, I should, after probing, you're saying there was time that this Court has never held that that -- what did you say about it?
That if there is time you must get a warrant, have we ever -- have we ever held that as adoption or said merely because there was time, doesn't exclude consideration of other factors.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, in Rabinowitz --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: In the matters of (Inaudible) --

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: It seems to me in Rabinowitz, you express the overrule of the Trupiano case in -- in which there was a requirement if there was time to get the search warrant and you expressly overrule that.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But that case (Inaudible) doesn't matter.
The -- the Rabinowitz case went on some petition or ground, didn't it?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: It didn't say it's an immaterial factor.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, there -- in this case you -- we must look at the fact that this wasn't done for the purpose of getting any search or seizure at all.
That isn't what they went there for.
They were going to deport him.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That's what I mean but this doesn't -- therefore, you defend this man.
It doesn't matter whether there was time or not.
You justify the legality of it being an independent ground.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And the mere fact that there was time you argued doesn't displace those other legalizing evidence, isn't not what the position you take?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes, because the -- the discovery, the search and the seizure were --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Within the course of -- of illegal enterprise.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That's your position.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: And it was a lawful entry and lawful action, and so the search and seizure were lawfully.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And you transfer that which was legal with reference to the pursuit that was made, i.e. deportation, does not bar the use of testimony so secured in what subsequent they became a criminal prosecution and that's your position?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: That's right.
The -- all of the reasons for applying those principles in the criminal cases are here in regard to this deportation case.
And so we say that if a person being prosecuted for a crime would not be this -- be barred from such a search and seizure.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I'm still troubled by what seems to me a necessary (Inaudible) and I'd say he can't be taken but it does require a transfer.
You argue in the first place that the restrictions as to search and seizure that applied to an unembarrassed or an unequivocal criminal prosecution --

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- if this was just a criminal prosecution, for all I know, you wouldn't be here defending.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: No, this would satisfy all the requirements of Harris or Rabinowitz in that event.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: So you don't -- you don't have to rely on the deportation proceeding.

I thought you do -- you do rely on it and say since what you've got, you got in the course of a proceeding which is legal because it is for purpose of the deportation, you then had a windfall and you can process by the windfall in the criminal prosecution.
That's what I call making a jump, that because you would be justified in using this materials under this procedure to be brought in, you're also justified in using it in order to convict him.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, I agree with your last statement but I say that if it was a criminal proceeding as distinguished from one for deportation, it would come within all standards and requirements of Harris and Rabinowitz.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: In other words, you've got two grounds and say you -- you got this in a legal -- in a legal deportation proceeding, therefore, you can use it, there's no taint to it, but in any event, you say even if you didn't have that, the search and seizure here were incident, your lawful arrest when you could -- you could have made these things to move, legally made procedure and to get the benefit of it, is that right?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, that's the question that Justice Brennan asked me, and I said I think that's true but I don't think we argued that before in the other two courts and so the Court -- unless they will let us argue that here the first time.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, that's what I'm -- that's why I asked you the question earlier that I want to be clear that you are resting upon the legality of this -- use of this administrative warrant and nothing more.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, I -- I would argue that the arrest was legal in regard to the criminal matters.

There was probable cause for the officers to be there but I'm arguing, I want to clearly understood for the first time in this Court and it was not argued in the Court of Appeals or the District Court to sustain.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I don't think that bar you from arguing anymore to debar me from sustaining their judgment below on a ground which the Court of Appeals didn't take.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, you may not be willing to grant it to me but I'm arguing it anyway on both grounds and I think they're both there.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I'm glad now that it came up again because I have the other understanding from your answer to --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: As I understand your argument -- your answer to Justice Frankfurter is that you say you have a right to search incident to an administrative arrest that the scope of that right to search is certainly no narrower than the scope under Harris, that testing their search by the Harris standards is good as an administrative search, isn't -- isn't that -- isn't that what you meant?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: I -- I answer it that way and I also add that it was a lawful -- there was probable cause for an arrest because of conspiracy to commit espionage and for violation of the statute about reporting to the Attorney General.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: In other words -- well, that's Justice Brennan's question and I have --

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: -- the same confusion that he does.
I understood you to say to him first that if your administrative search defense was not accepted by the Court, you then felt that you would -- could not testify this on any other ground.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: I said we didn't argue before the other two courts on any other ground.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: But you --

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: But I do think that there's adequate ground here.
There was probable cause for arrest for the criminal matters that I have described.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: The reason you don't argue it, I take it, is because of what we said in the Giordenello case --

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: That's what bothers --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: -- that these people did not have a chance to justify the reasonableness of the search on a basis that wasn't advanced by you there.
That's the problem and you're rubbing it.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: But -- yes.
But I still want you to consider it, if you will.
I think --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: I understand.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: -- it's all there and the facts were all there.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: But you're committed (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes, that's admitted.
It's clear in the record and there is no question about it.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Now, of course, if there had been that kind of arrest by the F.B.I., the arrest would have been followed by immediately under the Criminal Code of Procedure by -- by an arraignment and under which this man would have had various protections.
That's true, isn't it?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, yes, but I don't think that would affect the search or the seizure.
That would affect whether or not the due process from then on.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: From then on.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: I think --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But -- but wouldn't it shed a light under justification, if you do not treat -- so if you do not treat the seizure as incident to an arrest for which you have probable cause and you do not so treat it because you do not follow the consequences, as Mr. Justice Stewart just suggest, then you can justify it because the conduct negative the justification.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, if we had done that, you would say it was a mere subterfuge or device to get the evidence for that purpose instead of for purposes of deportation.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You mean if we have done what?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: If we had gone and --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: -- and claimed that it was an arrest --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But you can claim it's an arrest for purpose of search and seizure, but not an arrest for purpose of protecting him in a way in which an arrested person is protected.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, if all --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You can't -- I don't think you can do that.
I think --

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: If there's probable cause, there is -- the question is whether the officers are lawfully there.
Now, if there's probable cause, they are lawfully there in -- in order to make an arrest and the rest of it, the search and seizure follows just like day after night.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes, but the probability is negative by the fact that you don't draw the consequences of what -- of what you justify as probability for the purpose of seizing and it exhaust itself in seizing and therefore, one has a right to say, you seize because you wanted to seize and not because it was incident to an arrest.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, if the probable cause is there as admitted here --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You don't say it does evaporate.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: It doesn't disappear.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: And that's the justification for the search and seizure.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: To me, all the shed light --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: May I ask you one question to get clarification, I don't quite understand.
Suppose there had been no so-called administrative warrant at hold, would your argument has been different?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: I would have argued throughout.
And the Department would argue in the lower courts that there was probable cause in regard at least two offenses, criminal offences, and there was ample ground for search and seizure at all times.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Without -- you do not put and it relies then on the administrative warrant.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: I rely on both by --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Oh, how can you rely on it?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Because we did have one.
That is the fact.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But would it comply?
Could -- could the F.B.I. issue a warrant like that without going to a magistrate to arrest the man for crime?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes, they could -- they wouldn't issue the warrant but the warrant was issued under the statute.
The --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I understand that.
I'm talking about the Fourth Amendment.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, if it was in regard to a crime?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: They wouldn't have to have the -- a warrant.
They had probable cause to arrest the man right there.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Then I understand that what you are saying is, that's what I asked, maybe I'm wrong, that they didn't have to have anyone either from a magistrate or from the administrative officer for whatever that's worth.
I don't know what its worth.
You're saying they didn't have to have any warrant because they had probable cause to go in and arrest.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Without a warrant?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Without a warrant?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I don't understand that.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: That was a -- a crime was being committed right then.
He was not reporting --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But when they got on the premises -- they got on the premises because in their head, there was a conviction that there was probable cause and if that is true, then they have no business, as I understand it, then they would have to get a warrant for his arrest.
You say they knew they had all this fact in their head, that constituted probable cause.
I suggest it constitutes probable cause for getting a warrant for arrest but not for going in and arresting him.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, if the -- the -- there are cases by the Court that if there are acts in their presence that amount to a commission of a crime that that's probable cause.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What -- what acts were they permitted in, except the evidence of what the basis on which they proceeded with?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: He was at that time claimed to be Martin Collins under a fraudulent birth certificate in their presence and that was a -- a violation of the statutes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, then, the consequences of this is far-reaching, Mr. Solicitor, being that if arrest -- if -- if the Department of Justice officials have good reasons for getting a warrant of arrest for a man but they don't get a warrant of arrest, they enter his premises, they ask him a question, they have every reason to believe that he's going to lie, they now say, "Oh, you liar because we know that isn't your true name."
That would make hash of the duty to get a warrant of arrest as well as the duty to get a warrant for search.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Well, as -- as I understand your brief (Inaudible) being led to making an argument by the questions of the Court if you don't make in your brief --

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: -- in other words, you do not depend in your brief the search and seizure independently of its being a valid search incident to be administrative arrest.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: And you draw assessments from the Giordenello case on another basis, namely, when you come to answering your adversary's arguments as to the scope of the search you say therefore, closed in raising that up here because they didn't raise it below and under the Giordenello doctrine, they can't be heard to argue that when you had no opportunity to depend them on that score in the court below.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: So that you were --

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: As to dilemma --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: It seems to me you are being -- you are being led into an argument here which puts you in an inconsistent position and it's quite different from the one that you make in your brief.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: That's correct, Mr. Justice.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And I may say that I'm puzzled still.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Maybe it -- maybe it is contrary to what your argument is as being imposed with me.
Do you think if the Fourth Amendment is justifying no less by for administrative warrant, then it is for a warrant by a magistrate?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, no.
I think there is a different kind of a problem.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, why would the administration have -- administrative agents have more right to bring about the arrest of the man under the Fourth Amendment?
Another circumstance is different to what the courts -- through magistrate to him.
I don't get that.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, because you have a -- a crime involves punishment.
This Court has held that deportation does not involve punishment.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But the Fourth Amendment, it talks about arrest and seizure.
It doesn't talk about punishment, does it?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, I don't think that this is -- rest in that sense, although, it's taking a person in custody in order to carry out the deportation.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But was seized.
He is seized by officers.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes, that's the --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Do I understand --

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: -- the effect of it.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- that the Government is -- I -- I want to get this clearly in my own mind because I have somewhat different ideas about this, the fact of the Search and Seizure Clause of the Constitution and some of the -- and some of the other.

Do I understand that the Government is taking the position here that administrative agents can issue warrant to seize a man because they say it's something administratively where they're not going to punish him that would -- would not meet the requirements of the Fourth Amendment, so far the magistrates are concern?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, our argument is that you shouldn't certainly impose a more stricter rule on that kind of a warrant and an arrest where they come in lawfully under such in a warrant than you do in a criminal case and therefore, this at least complies with all of the Court's requirements in Harris and Rabinowitz for -- if this was a criminal procedure.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, my -- when this case came up, we brought it here, I suppose the point was the difference between -- if there was any difference between the Fourth Amendment's requirement in connection with administrative arrest or -- for deportation or anything else and any other.

Now, I can understand your argument if you are saying that under the Fourth Amendment, you had probable cause to make this arrest and that the circumstances will not search to make it unreasonable to go and arrest him without going -- to go magistrate.
But I do not in my circuits, where you can get much help from this so-called administrative warrant, nobody swore anything.
It wasn't before a magistrate and it just -- just an order from one superior to another to go arrest the man and seize him.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, the same -- same factors for the search and seizure are involved in that kind of an arrest that is protection of the man making the arrest that are involved in a criminal arrest.
And so we take the position that you should not apply a stricter rule to that kind of arrest than you do to the other.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, I can understand that.
If that's what you're arguing, then I don't see whether the administrative warrant had anything to do with it.
If that's to be given much weight, I -- I haven't yet seen -- heard the argument which justifies it --

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- under the Fourth Amendment.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: If you recognize that he has to be taken into custody in order to deport him like the Court has a number of times in different cases, then you have to -- it seems to me, you have to follow out just like you have in the criminal cases that there has to be some search, at least to this person, so that they don't kill the officer that's making the arrest.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You go back to the validity of the arrest --

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- without a warrant under the Fourth Amendment.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well -- but I don't want you to misunderstand me.
I will -- I am the warrant of the Immigration Service and I --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) understand.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: -- which is an authorization to take possession of this man, take him into custody.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You claim that administrative agent has a right to order somebody seized without going before a magistrate even though there's ample time, nobody doubts this ample time that they can go grab him whenever they see fit without going before magistrate and seize him and whisk him away.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, that's been done for great many years when the Court has tacitly at least in the Carlson case recognized.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: The statute of Congress purports to authorize it.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Your opponents don't question this case.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: No, they admit that the -- the arrest was proper.
It was conceded throughout the -- the lower courts.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: In effect of making the so-called administrative office‘s magistrate, is that right?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, it's still less than a criminal proceeding.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: With the Chief Justice's permission, I must trouble you with one more question, and I think I am praying on your side as on that in this question.

The Giordenello case, let's get things straight, I will understand that if the Government or anybody else seeks to justify a judgment on a theory which would have involved examination of a witness in order to determine the validity of the theory and those such examination was made or opportunity given because the theory wasn't advanced, you can't espouse that theory in sustaining the judgment.
That's Giordenello.

You got a different doctrine which may or may not be applicable to this situation that if the record that it comes here permits sustaining a judgment which doesn't require any testimony to contradict or to qualify, but on the face of the record permits the judgment to be vindicated on a theory not advanced for anybody neither counsel or the lower court.

This Court is not debarred, indeed it -- its duty to sustain that judgment because we hear review judgments and not talk and therefore, I suggested to you, that you could sustain this judgment on any theory so not advanced heretofore subject to the qualification of the Giordenello case, namely, that it wouldn't have required examination of witnesses because in the Giordenello case, what was involved for the examination of witnesses in order to satisfy, if it could be satisfied, the requirements of Texas law.

I do not know on this record whether the second theory, the other theory, which you say you advanced here for the first time, namely, that on this record, the arrest and the search were justified, not merely on the administrative process so-called but because a crime was committed in the presence of the arresting officers and the searching officers.

If the record sustains that, then I think you'll open to sustaining it on that ground and this Court is -- is open and entitled to it, indeed must, if it can sustain the judgment below on that ground.
Those are two very different things.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: We think that the record so sustains and the record was made by the petitioner, we're calling (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, it -- it may have been by the petitioner but on the basis of the issue as shaped by the Government.

And that would -- if that is so, and the testimony might bring out a -- a different result, then you would in Giordenello, but if the record doesn't present such a situation, then Giordenello has nothing to do with the case.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, I think the testimony was exhausted on that question.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: All right.
Then it isn't Giordenello.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Now, what crime was being a crime or crimes that was being committed in the presence of the arresting officer?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: He was claiming to -- trying to maintain a fictitious identify and was not -- at that time had not reported and was not reporting at the moment his location in violation of the statute.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Now, would that then to say that the possession of the two birth certificates or the vaccination certificate and of the bank book were evidence of the commission in the presence of officers of that crime?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: And he also stated that his name was Martin Collins.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: So that -- those then were the evidence of the commission in their presence of the crime you just described.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Now, as to the code up the sleeve, what was that?

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: That was evidence of the espionage.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Commission of the crime of espionage.

turn.speaker: j_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. J. Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Donovan.

turn.speaker: james_b_donovan
turn.label: Mr. James B. Donovan
turn.text: May it please the Court.
Although I reserved time for a reply, I'll make no detailed reply.
I believe that most of the arguments that I'd set forth are contained in my reply brief, which I commend to your earnest asserting.
However, I should like to -- to make a -- a few observations with respect to some of these matters that have been brought out this morning on questioning by the Court.
Mr. Justice Brennan, this discussion of seven items can be very misleading.
If I could direct your attention to page 41 of our brief, Appendix C, Your Honor will find that there are over 40 items involved here --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.
So were they all taken from the Latham, Mr. Donovan, or (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: james_b_donovan
turn.label: Mr. James B. Donovan
turn.text: Either -- either, Your Honor, as you will see, that all of these items were used by the Department of Justice in the case and they were either seized in Latham or else obtained in the studio on a search warrant, which was obtained solely by residing everything found at the Latham.
So that all of these items, we believe under the decisions of this Court, are involved in this case.
That's point number one.
Our point --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Were they admitted into evidence under those --

turn.speaker: james_b_donovan
turn.label: Mr. James B. Donovan
turn.text: These are all set forth, Your Honor, in Appendix C.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: But --

turn.speaker: james_b_donovan
turn.label: Mr. James B. Donovan
turn.text: Those --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) admitted into evidence of the crime?

turn.speaker: james_b_donovan
turn.label: Mr. James B. Donovan
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: james_b_donovan
turn.label: Mr. James B. Donovan
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, as exhibits and we've -- we've listed here not only -- not only on page 41, not only identification of the record where it was offered but also where received.
Now, second --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: The exhibit number, if you give the exhibit numbers, those are admitted into evidence.

turn.speaker: james_b_donovan
turn.label: Mr. James B. Donovan
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: james_b_donovan
turn.label: Mr. James B. Donovan
turn.text: Now, secondly --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Now, I just -- are you telling us that this exhibit shown on page (Inaudible) Appendix C.
It all takes it from petitioner's room on his (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: james_b_donovan
turn.label: Mr. James B. Donovan
turn.text: Your -- Your Honor, to clarify for the Court, we have divided them into four different categories.
Item C is to the Latham which were introduced as exhibits.
Item C is to the Latham which were used to obtain the exhibits introduced.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Well, talking about derivative matters, now.

turn.speaker: james_b_donovan
turn.label: Mr. James B. Donovan
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, these are under the decisions of this Court and of the Second Circuit.
